sections.title: Football's Role in Physical Rehabilitation and Therapy

nodes.data: Football's Role in Physical Rehabilitation and Therapy

Football isn't just a globally beloved sport; it also plays a significant role in physical rehabilitation and therapy. Integrating football into recovery programs can harness the power of sport to improve physical and mental health. According to
Mayo Clinic research
, structured sport activities like football can enhance coordination, flexibility, and strength, crucial elements in physical rehabilitation.
Moreover, the team environment and competitive nature of football provide psychological benefits by boosting morale and motivation during the recovery process.
Johns Hopkins Medicine

highlights the importance of these psychological aspects in speeding up recovery. Engaging in football, under the guidance of physiotherapy professionals, ensures that the activity is both safe and effective, aligning with
NHS guidelines
on therapeutic exercises.
Thus, incorporating football into a physiotherapy plan not only aids in physical recovery but also rekindles the joy and social interaction that enhances overall wellbeing.

sections.title: The Broader Impact of Football on Physical and Psychological Well-being

nodes.data: The Broader Impact of Football on Physical and Psychological Well-being

Football isn't just a game; it's a powerful activity with extensive benefits for both physical and psychological health. Engaging in football can significantly enhance cardiovascular fitness and muscle strength, aspects strongly supported by
Mayo Clinic research

. Beyond the physical, the sport offers a remarkable avenue for stress relief and mental resilience. Players often experience a boost in self-esteem and a decrease in anxiety levels, aligning with findings from
Johns Hopkins Medicine
. Furthermore, the team-oriented nature of football fosters social connections, enhancing emotional well-being, a benefit highlighted by
Cleveland Clinic’s insights
. Thus, football is more than just physical training; it’s a holistic approach to health.

sections.title: Introduction to the Dynamics of Kicking a Football

nodes.data: Introduction to the Dynamics of Kicking a Football

Kicking a football effectively involves a complex interplay of biomechanics and physical conditioning. As you prepare to return to the pitch after physiotherapy, understanding the dynamics of this action can significantly enhance your performance and prevent re-injury. According to
Mayo Clinic research
, mastering the technique of kicking not only involves the legs but also engages the core and upper body, ensuring stability and power. Rehabilitation strategies, as outlined by
Johns Hopkins Medicine

sections.title: The Role of Physiotherapy in Enhancing Football Skills

nodes.data: The Role of Physiotherapy in Enhancing Football Skills

Physiotherapy plays a crucial role in not only recovering from football injuries but also in enhancing the overall skills necessary for the sport. Tailored physiotherapy programs can significantly improve flexibility, strength, and coordination, which are vital for a football player's performance on the pitch. According to
Mayo Clinic research
, targeted exercises and therapy techniques can lead to improved muscle control and kicking precision, which are essential for football.
Moreover, physiotherapy aids in the correction of posture and body mechanics. This aspect is critical as it helps in reducing the risk of re-injury and enhances the efficiency of football movements.
Cleveland Clinic's insights

into physical therapy highlight how rehabilitation focuses on specific muscular groups and joints used predominantly in football, thereby tailoring recovery to meet the unique needs of football players.
Additionally, physiotherapists can provide guidance on injury prevention strategies and conditioning routines that help athletes maintain peak physical condition throughout the season. According to
Johns Hopkins Medicine
, such preventive measures are integral in a sport as dynamic and physically demanding as football.
Incorporating regular physiotherapy sessions can thus be a game-changer for football enthusiasts looking to enhance their skills and enjoy the game with reduced injury risks.

sections.title: Preventive Measures and Rehabilitation for Football Players

nodes.data: Preventive Measures and Rehabilitation for Football Players
Returning to the football pitch after an injury requires not just healing but also strategic prevention to avoid future issues. According to
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy

, incorporating specific exercises that strengthen the muscles used in football can significantly reduce the risk of re-injury. These exercises often focus on enhancing core stability, leg strength, and flexibility, which are crucial for football players who constantly engage in kicking and rapid directional changes.
Rehabilitation plays a pivotal role in ensuring players not only recover but also improve their physical capabilities.
Mayo Clinic research

highlights the importance of tailored rehabilitation programs that address the unique demands of football. These programs often include a combination of strength training, proprioceptive exercises, and sport-specific drills to ensure a safe and effective return to the sport.
Furthermore,
Cleveland Clinic's advice

on early intervention with physiotherapy post-injury underscores the benefit of starting rehabilitation as soon as possible. This approach helps maintain fitness levels and minimises the psychological impact of being away from the sport, facilitating a smoother transition back to full football activity.
Lastly, monitoring progress and adjusting rehabilitation goals as recovery advances are essential. This adaptive strategy, as supported by
Johns Hopkins Medicine
, ensures that each phase of recovery is optimally managed, paving the way for a successful and enjoyable return to football.

faqs.question: What should I expect when treating football enjoying again after physio?
faqs.answer: Treatment depends on severity. Initially, expect assessment, personalized exercises, and advice. Most patients see improvement within 2-4 weeks of consistent treatment.

faqs.question: How long does recovery from football enjoying again after physio typically take?
faqs.answer: Recovery varies by individual and severity. Mild cases may resolve in weeks, while complex cases may require several months of targeted physiotherapy.

faqs.question: Can physiotherapy prevent football enjoying again after physio from returning?
faqs.answer: Yes. Strengthening exercises, proper posture, and ergonomic adjustments significantly reduce recurrence risk.

faqs.question: Is football enjoying again after physio painful to treat?
faqs.answer: Physiotherapy aims to reduce pain progressively. Some discomfort is normal during rehabilitation, but treatment should not cause sharp pain.

checklist: ✓ Apply ice/heat as advised for pain management

reviews.text: Jordan is an outstanding physio. From my initial appointment to my assessment, he was professional, knowledgeable, and reassuring. He clearly explained my hand injury and the proposed treatment approach. I left feeling confident and well supported. A great initial experience, and I would totally recommend him to anyone seeking expert physiotherapy care.

After a long time away from playing football, I decided to get back into and had some frustrating injuries getting in the way. After my first assessment from Jordan, he identified my underlying issues and set out a recovery and rehab programme. It didn’t take long to start seeing the benefits. With regular sessions we dealt with any new issues but continued work on the root cause. After great mix of hands on physio and pitch sessions I am now feeling in great condition. The nutritional advice along with pre and post game conditioning routines given, I feel will help me continue with the great progress and prolong my time in football. Been a top class experience with Jordan from start till now and the physical benefits and knowledge I am taking away is priceless.
I have been struggling with knee pain for 2 years and after a block of treatment with Jordan my pain is all but gone. Would absolutely recommend him to anyone.
Excellent service and very clear on what the issue is and a plan going forward.  Thanks very much

sections.title: Understanding Running Physiotherapy: What It Is and Why It Matters

nodes.data: Understanding Running Physiotherapy: What It Is and Why It Matters

Running physiotherapy is a specialised branch of physiotherapy focused on the needs of runners. This form of therapy aims to prevent injuries, improve running efficiency, and enhance overall performance. According to
Mayo Clinic research

, targeted exercises and techniques are used to address the unique mechanical demands of running. It's not just about treating injuries; it's also about implementing preventive measures and recovery protocols. The importance of running physio cannot be overstated, as it helps runners maintain their physical health and ensures longevity in the sport. As highlighted by
Johns Hopkins Medicine
, tailored rehabilitation services can significantly aid in the rapid recovery from running-related injuries, making it a crucial aspect of any runner's training regimen.

sections.title: The Core Benefits of Running Physiotherapy for Athletes

nodes.data: The Core Benefits of Running Physiotherapy for Athletes

Running physiotherapy offers numerous advantages tailored specifically for athletes, enhancing both performance and recovery. One primary benefit is the improvement in joint mobility and muscle flexibility, which are crucial for maintaining optimal running form and efficiency. According to
Mayo Clinic research
, tailored physiotherapy programs can significantly reduce the risk of running-related injuries by strengthening key muscle groups and correcting biomechanical imbalances.
Moreover,
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy

highlight the role of personalised rehabilitation plans in speeding up recovery from injuries. This is particularly vital for athletes who need to return to their peak condition swiftly and safely. Additionally, physiotherapy provides strategic pain management techniques, which are essential for athletes managing chronic conditions or recovering from surgery, as supported by
Johns Hopkins Medicine
These structured physio programs not only enhance athletic performance but also promote long-term health and well-being, making them indispensable for runners at all levels.

sections.title: Comprehensive Guide to Running Physiotherapy Techniques and Exercises

nodes.data: Understanding Running-Related Injuries and Prevention
Running is an excellent form of physical activity but comes with its risks, particularly if done improperly. According to
Mayo Clinic research

, understanding the biomechanics of running and the importance of adequate warm-up routines can significantly reduce the risk of injuries. It's crucial for runners to incorporate specific physiotherapy exercises that enhance flexibility, strength, and endurance, thus ensuring a safer running experience.
Key Physiotherapy Exercises for Runners
Physiotherapy provides a foundation for not only recovery but also for injury prevention in runners.
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy

recommend exercises such as hamstring stretches, calf raises, and core strengthening to support running mechanics. These exercises help in building the necessary muscle strength and flexibility required to withstand the repetitive impact of running, potentially reducing the occurrence of common issues like runner's knee or shin splints.
Advanced Techniques for Optimal Performance
For those looking to enhance their running performance, incorporating advanced physiotherapy techniques can be beneficial. Techniques such as gait analysis and manual therapy, as outlined by
Cleveland Clinic's physical therapy services

, can help in identifying and correcting form, which not only improves efficiency but also minimizes injury risk. Tailored exercise regimens that focus on balance and proprioceptive training are also essential components for seasoned runners aiming to optimize their performance.

By integrating these physiotherapy techniques and exercises into your routine, you can enjoy the benefits of running while minimizing the risk of injury. Always consult with a qualified physiotherapist to ensure the exercises and techniques are appropriately tailored to your individual needs.

sections.title: Understanding Knee Injuries

nodes.data: Understanding Knee Injuries

Knee injuries are a common concern for runners, ranging from acute damage like ligament tears to chronic conditions such as runner's knee or patellofemoral pain syndrome. Understanding the nature of these injuries and how they can impact your running is crucial for effective recovery and prevention.

One prevalent injury among runners is the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear, which can occur due to sudden stops or changes in direction. This type of injury not only affects stability but also significantly hampers mobility, making early and targeted intervention vital. According to
Mayo Clinic research
, physiotherapy plays a key role in recovering from ACL injuries, helping to restore joint function and strength.

Another common issue is the patellofemoral pain syndrome, often referred to as runner's knee. This condition is characterised by pain around the kneecap and is typically exacerbated by activities like running, squatting, and ascending stairs. Effective management strategies, as outlined by
Johns Hopkins Medicine
, include both physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles and specific exercises to ensure proper knee alignment during physical activities.

Meniscus tears are also frequent in the running community, resulting from forceful twisting or rotation of the knee joint. Treatment options vary depending on the severity of the tear, but physiotherapy remains a cornerstone for recovery, helping to improve flexibility and decrease pain. Insight from
Cleveland Clinic
highlights the importance of a personalised therapy plan that addresses the unique needs of each runner, focusing on healing and preventing future injuries.
Understanding these injuries and their treatments can significantly influence recovery outcomes for runners. Adhering to
NHS guidelines

on rehabilitation exercises and recovery programs is essential for regaining strength and returning to running safely and effectively. Each runner's journey to recovery will differ, but with the right knowledge and support, overcoming a knee injury is entirely achievable.

A great initial experience, and I would totally recommend him to anyone seeking expert physiotherapy care.

After a long time away from playing football, I decided to get back into and had some frustrating injuries getting in the way. After my first assessment from Jordan, he identified my underlying issues and set out a recovery and rehab programme. It didn’t take long to start seeing the benefits. With regular sessions we dealt with any new issues but continued work on the root cause. After great mix of hands on physio and pitch sessions I am now feeling in great condition. The nutritional advice along with pre and post game conditioning routines given, I feel will help me continue with the great progress and prolong my time in football. Been a top class experience with Jordan from start till now and the physical benefits and knowledge I am taking away is priceless.
I have been struggling with knee pain for 2 years and after a block of treatment with Jordan my pain is all but gone. Would absolutely recommend him to anyone.
Excellent service and very clear on what the issue is and a plan going forward.  Thanks very much

sections.title: Understanding Knee Injuries

nodes.data: Understanding Knee Injuries

Knee injuries are a common concern among runners, stemming from the repetitive impact and strain that running places on the knee joint. Understanding the types of knee injuries and their causes can significantly aid in effective recovery and prevention strategies.

One of the most prevalent knee injuries in runners is the patellofemoral pain syndrome, often referred to as runner's knee. This condition is characterised by pain around the kneecap and is typically caused by overuse, misalignment, and muscular imbalances. According to
expert recommendations from Johns Hopkins Medicine
, addressing the muscular imbalances through targeted physical therapy can be an effective treatment approach.

Another common issue is the iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS), which occurs when the connective tissue that runs from the hip to the shin becomes tight and inflamed. This condition can cause significant pain on the outside of the knee. The
Cleveland Clinic's guide to physical therapy
suggests that specific stretching and strengthening exercises can alleviate symptoms and prevent the recurrence of ITBS.

Meniscal tears are also frequent among runners, particularly those involved in activities requiring sudden turns and stops. These tears can vary in severity and sometimes require surgical intervention. However, as noted in the
Mayo Clinic research on physiotherapy
, non-surgical treatments like physiotherapy can also support recovery by improving knee function and strength.

Lastly, ligament injuries such as ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) tears are severe but less common. They often occur during accidents or improper landing from a jump. Rehabilitation for such injuries is comprehensive and long-term, focusing on restoring joint stability and mobility.
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy
outline the structured recovery programs that are vital for regaining full function post-injury.

For runners, understanding these injuries and their treatment options is crucial. Implementing appropriate recovery protocols and preventive measures can help maintain knee health and enhance running performance.

faqs.question: What should I expect when treating Knee Injury Recovery for Runners?
faqs.answer: Treatment depends on severity. Initially, expect assessment, personalized exercises, and advice. Most patients see improvement within 2-4 weeks of consistent treatment.

faqs.question: How long does recovery from Knee Injury Recovery for Runners typically take?
faqs.answer: Recovery varies by individual and severity. Mild cases may resolve in weeks, while complex cases may require several months of targeted physiotherapy.

faqs.question: Can physiotherapy prevent Knee Injury Recovery for Runners from returning?
faqs.answer: Yes. Strengthening exercises, proper posture, and ergonomic adjustments significantly reduce recurrence risk.

faqs.question: Is Knee Injury Recovery for Runners painful to treat?
faqs.answer: Physiotherapy aims to reduce pain progressively. Some discomfort is normal during rehabilitation, but treatment should not cause sharp pain.

checklist: ✓ Apply ice/heat as advised for pain management
✓ Maintain proper posture throughout the day
✓ Track pain levels and progress in journal
✓ Return to activities gradually as cleared

sections.title: Recovery Tips

nodes.data: Recovery Tips

Navigating the path to recovery after a sports injury requires a well-structured approach. One key aspect is adhering to a personalised rehabilitation program, which should include a combination of rest, structured exercise, and possibly manual therapy
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy
. It's crucial to allow the body adequate time to heal while gradually reintroducing it to physical activity.
Incorporating a variety of rehabilitation exercises can significantly enhance the recovery process.
Mayo Clinic research

highlights the importance of tailored exercises that address not only the injured area but also overall body strength and conditioning. This holistic approach helps prevent future injuries by ensuring the body maintains balance and strength.

Moreover, regular assessments and adjustments to your recovery plan are essential. Tools and tests used in physical therapy can track progress and pinpoint areas needing additional focus. According to
Johns Hopkins Medicine
, using objective recovery tests helps in making informed decisions about the intensity and type of exercises during rehabilitation.
Lastly, consulting with a certified therapist from resources like the
American Physical Therapy Association
can provide you with access to expert advice and guidance tailored to your specific sports injury and recovery needs. This professional support is invaluable in safely returning to peak performance.

sections.title: Understanding Injury Physiotherapy: An Overview

nodes.data: Understanding Injury Physiotherapy: An Overview
Injury physiotherapy is a crucial branch of healthcare that focuses on aiding patients in recovering from injuries through physical methods, rather than medication. According to
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy
, this can include exercises, manual therapy, and advice tailored to individual needs, enhancing recovery and function.
Mayo Clinic research

also supports the use of physiotherapy to manage pain and improve mobility, which is particularly beneficial following sports injuries, accidents, or surgeries. By employing a range of techniques, physiotherapists help patients regain strength and movement, promoting a quicker and safer return to daily activities. This integrative approach not only aids in physical recovery but also empowers patients with the knowledge and tools needed for self-management and prevention of future injuries.

sections.contentHtml:
Understanding Injury Physiotherapy: An Overview

Injury physiotherapy is a crucial branch of healthcare that focuses on aiding patients in recovering from injuries through physical methods, rather than medication. According to NHS guidelines on physiotherapy, this can include exercises, manual therapy, and advice tailored to individual needs, enhancing recovery and function. Mayo Clinic research also supports the use of physiotherapy to manage pain and improve mobility, which is particularly beneficial following sports injuries, accidents, or surgeries. By employing a range of techniques, physiotherapists help patients regain strength and movement, promoting a quicker and safer return to daily activities. This integrative approach not only aids in physical recovery but also empowers patients with the knowledge and tools needed for self-management and prevention of future injuries.

sections.title: The Benefits of Physiotherapy for Injury Recovery

nodes.data: The Benefits of Physiotherapy for Injury Recovery
Physiotherapy plays a pivotal role in the recovery process following an injury. It not only accelerates the healing period but also decreases the risk of future re-injury.
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy
emphasise the importance of tailored exercises that improve mobility and strengthen the affected areas. According to
Mayo Clinic research
, physio also significantly enhances pain management, a crucial aspect for those recovering from injuries. Moreover,
Cleveland Clinic's insights

suggest that engaging in guided physical therapy sessions helps restore function more effectively than rest alone. This comprehensive approach ensures a safer and more efficient return to daily activities, underpinning the essential role of physio in injury rehabilitation.

sections.contentHtml:
The Benefits of Physiotherapy for Injury Recovery

Physiotherapy plays a pivotal role in the recovery process following an injury. It not only accelerates the healing period but also decreases the risk of future re-injury. NHS guidelines on physiotherapy emphasise the importance of tailored exercises that improve mobility and strengthen the affected areas. According to Mayo Clinic research, physio also significantly enhances pain management, a crucial aspect for those recovering from injuries. Moreover, Cleveland Clinic's insights suggest that engaging in guided physical therapy sessions helps restore function more effectively than rest alone. This comprehensive approach ensures a safer and more efficient return to daily activities, underpinning the essential role of physio in injury rehabilitation.

sections.title: How Injury Physiotherapy Works: Techniques and Treatments

nodes.data: How Injury Physiotherapy Works: Techniques and Treatments
Injury physiotherapy focuses on aiding recovery through a blend of manual therapies, exercises, and advanced modalities. According to
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy
, tailored exercise programmes play a crucial role in strengthening injured areas and improving flexibility. Furthermore,
Mayo Clinic research
highlights the importance of manual therapy techniques such as massage and mobilisation, which help decrease pain and enhance movement.
Johns Hopkins Medicine

also emphasises the use of specialised treatments like ultrasound or electrical stimulation for reducing inflammation and promoting tissue healing. Each treatment plan is customised to the patient's specific needs, ensuring a more effective and efficient path to recovery. By integrating these multiple approaches, injury physiotherapy not only accelerates recovery but also minimises the risk of future injuries, supporting a healthier, more active lifestyle.

sections.title: Understanding Shoulder Pain and the Role of Physiotherapy

nodes.data: Understanding Shoulder Pain and the Role of Physiotherapy

Shoulder pain can significantly impact your daily activities, stemming from various causes such as injuries, arthritis, or repetitive stress. Physiotherapy plays a crucial role in managing and alleviating shoulder pain. Through tailored exercises, physiotherapy helps to strengthen shoulder muscles, enhance flexibility, and reduce inflammation, thus facilitating a smoother recovery process.
Mayo Clinic research
highlights the importance of a personalised physiotherapy plan which adapts to the unique conditions and needs of each patient. Moreover,
NHS guidelines on physiotherapy

suggest that incorporating specific exercises under the guidance of a professional can expedite the healing process and prevent future complications. Engaging in physiotherapy not only helps relieve pain but also restores function and movement in the shoulder area, ensuring patients can return to their normal activities with improved ease and comfort.

sections.contentHtml:
Understanding Shoulder Pain and the Role of Physiotherapy

Shoulder pain can significantly impact your daily activities, stemming from various causes such as injuries, arthritis, or repetitive stress. Physiotherapy plays a crucial role in managing and alleviating shoulder pain. Through tailored exercises, physiotherapy helps to strengthen shoulder muscles, enhance flexibility, and reduce inflammation, thus facilitating a smoother recovery process.

Mayo Clinic research highlights the importance of a personalised physiotherapy plan which adapts to the unique conditions and needs of each patient. Moreover, NHS guidelines on physiotherapy suggest that incorporating specific exercises under the guidance of a professional can expedite the healing process and prevent future complications. Engaging in physiotherapy not only helps relieve pain but also restores function and movement in the shoulder area, ensuring patients can return to their normal activities with improved ease and comfort.

sections.title: Essential Physiotherapy Exercises for Alleviating Shoulder Pain

nodes.data: Essential Physiotherapy Exercises for Alleviating Shoulder Pain
Shoulder pain can significantly impact your daily activities, making effective physiotherapy exercises essential for recovery. According to
Mayo Clinic research

, gentle stretching and strengthening exercises can enhance mobility and reduce discomfort. A simple yet effective exercise is the pendulum stretch, which involves leaning forward slightly, allowing the affected arm to hang and swing in small circles. This movement helps to decrease stiffness.
Additionally,
NHS guidelines

recommend wall push-ups as a low-impact exercise to strengthen shoulder muscles without excessive strain. Begin standing arm's length from a wall, place your hands flat against it, and slowly lean your body forward, then push back to the starting position. These exercises, when performed regularly and under the guidance of a physiotherapist, can aid in mitigating shoulder pain and improving overall function.

sections.contentHtml:
Essential Physiotherapy Exercises for Alleviating Shoulder Pain

Shoulder pain can significantly impact your daily activities, making effective physiotherapy exercises essential for recovery. According to Mayo Clinic research, gentle stretching and strengthening exercises can enhance mobility and reduce discomfort. A simple yet effective exercise is the pendulum stretch, which involves leaning forward slightly, allowing the affected arm to hang and swing in small circles. This movement helps to decrease stiffness.

Additionally, NHS guidelines recommend wall push-ups as a low-impact exercise to strengthen shoulder muscles without excessive strain. Begin standing arm's length from a wall, place your hands flat against it, and slowly lean your body forward, then push back to the starting position. These exercises, when performed regularly and under the guidance of a physiotherapist, can aid in mitigating shoulder pain and improving overall function.

sections.title: Optimising Recovery: Tips and Best Practices

nodes.data: Optimising Recovery: Tips and Best Practices
Effective recovery from shoulder pain through physiotherapy hinges on adherence to a tailored exercise regimen and best practices that enhance healing.
Mayo Clinic research

highlights the importance of consistency in performing prescribed exercises, which can significantly expedite recovery times and improve outcomes. It is crucial to integrate these exercises into your daily routine to ensure continuous shoulder mobility and strength improvement.
Additionally,
NHS guidelines
suggest that alongside exercising, maintaining a balanced diet and proper hydration are vital, as nutrients and fluids play a key role in tissue repair and muscle function. Moreover,
Cleveland Clinic's recommendations
emphasise the need for adequate rest and sleep, which are essential for muscle recovery and pain management.
Following these expert-guided tips not only helps alleviate shoulder pain but also supports the overall success of your physiotherapy journey, leading to a quicker and more effective recovery.

sources.content: disappears entirely.AdvertisementHow can I prevent neck pain?You can take steps to prevent neck pain related to strains and tense muscles.Practice good posture. Position electronic devices, like computers and phones, so you don’t have to slouch or strain your neck when using them. Keep your shoulders aligned and your back straight when seated so you’re not straining your neck. Adjust the seats in your car to maintain good posture while traveling.Adjust your sleep position.Maintain good posture w

reviews.text: Jordan is an outstanding physio. From my initial appointment to my assessment, he was professional, knowledgeable, and reassuring. He clearly explained my hand injury and the proposed treatment approach. I left feeling confident and well supported. A great initial experience, and I would totally recommend him to anyone seeking expert physiotherapy care.

After a long time away from playing football, I decided to get back into and had some frustrating injuries getting in the way. After my first assessment from Jordan, he identified my underlying issues and set out a recovery and rehab programme. It didn’t take long to start seeing the benefits. With regular sessions we dealt with any new issues but continued work on the root cause. After great mix of hands on physio and pitch sessions I am now feeling in great condition. The nutritional advice along with pre and post game conditioning routines given, I feel will help me continue with the great progress and prolong my time in football. Been a top class experience with Jordan from start till now and the physical benefits and knowledge I am taking away is priceless.
I have been struggling with knee pain for 2 years and after a block of treatment with Jordan my pain is all but gone. Would absolutely recommend him to anyone.
Excellent service and very clear on what the issue is and a plan going forward.  Thanks very much
